  "article_text": [
    "in the late @xmath9 s , robert riley made a pioneering exploration of groups generated by two parabolic transformations .",
    "( his personal account of background history of the exploration can be found in @xcite . )",
    "the computer - drawn figure  [ fig.riley ] has been circulated among the experts and has inspired many researchers in the fields of kleinian groups and knot theory .",
    "the diagram plots the set @xmath10 of those complex numbers @xmath11 in the first quadrant of the complex plane for which the group @xmath12 is discrete and non - free .",
    "[ fig.riley ]    in @xcite , in which he mentions to the computer experiments and describes the algebra behind the experiments , riley introduced an infinite collection of laurent polynomials , which he calls the heckoid polynomials associated with a @xmath0-bridge link @xmath13 , and observed that these heckoid polynomials define the affine representation varieties of certain groups , the heckoid groups for @xmath13 .",
    "he `` defines '' the heckoid group of index @xmath14 for @xmath13 to be the kleinian group @xmath15 , where @xmath11 corresponds to a `` right '' root of the heckoid polynomials ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* the paragraph following theorem  a in p.390 ) ) .",
    "the classical hecke groups , introduced in @xcite , are essentially the simplest heckoid groups .",
    "he was convinced that `` the calculations for the diagram were pushed far enough to suggest that all essential phenomena were depicted '' , and observed the following @xcite :    1 .",
    "each @xmath16 such that @xmath15 is torsion - free corresponds to the hyperbolic structure on a @xmath0-bridge link complement .",
    "each @xmath16 such that @xmath15 is not torsion - free gives a heckoid group for some @xmath0-bridge link , or for the trivial knot .",
    "the points @xmath17 , @xmath18 , determining the heckoid groups for a @xmath0-bridge link @xmath13 converges to a cusp @xmath19 of the boundary of the region @xmath20 , the riley slice of the schottky space , i.e. , the set of complex numbers @xmath11 such that @xmath15 is discrete and free and the quotient @xmath21 of the domain of discontinuity @xmath22 is homeomorphic to the @xmath7-times punctured sphere .",
    "the classification of non - free @xmath0-parabolic generator kleinian groups announced by agol  @xcite , which generalizes the characterization of @xmath0-bridge links obtained by @xcite , justifies riley s anticipation .",
    "in fact , the classification theorem says that the heckoid groups and the @xmath0-bridge link groups , together with the @xmath0-parabolic generator subgroups of the classical hecke groups ( which are heckoid groups for the trivial knot ) , are the only non - free kleinian groups generated by two parabolic transformations .",
    "the announcement made in the second author s joint work with akiyoshi , wada and yamashita in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section  3 of preface ) ( cf .",
    "* remark  6.1 ) ) identifies the points @xmath17 , @xmath18 , as discrete points in the extension of a rational pleating ray studied by keen and series  @xcite ( cf .",
    "@xcite ) , converging to rational boundary points of the riley slice ( see figure  [ fig.yamashita ] copied from ( * ? ? ?",
    "* figure  0.2b ) ) . here , the endpoints of the extended rays correspond to @xmath0-bridge link groups .",
    "this note is an announcement of the series of papers  @xcite on heckoid groups motivated by riley s work  @xcite , in particular his systematic construction of epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto heckoid groups  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* the paragraph following theorem  b in p.391 ) .",
    "the purposes of the series of papers are the following .    1",
    ".   to give explicit combinatorial definitions of heckoid groups and heckoid orbifolds for @xmath0-bridge links , and to prove that the heckoid groups are identified with kleinian groups generated by two parabolic transformations .",
    "2 .   to establish results for _ even _ heckoid orbifolds corresponding to those for @xmath0-bridge links which are announced in @xcite and proved in the preceding series of papers @xcite .",
    "we note that the first purpose is essentially achieved in the announcement @xcite , but without proof .",
    "to explain the second purpose , we recall the preceding results mentioned in it . they are concerned with the following natural question , which in turn is regarded as a variation of a question raised by minsky  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* question  5.4 ) on essential simple loops on heegaard surfaces of @xmath23-manifolds .",
    "[ question0 ]    let @xmath13 be a knot or a link in @xmath24 and @xmath25 a punctured sphere in the complement @xmath26 obtained from a bridge sphere of @xmath13 .    1 .   which essential simple loops on @xmath25 are null - homotopic or peripheral in @xmath26 ?",
    "2 .   for two distinct essential simple loops on @xmath25 , when are they homotopic in @xmath26 ?    in the preceding series of papers , we gave a complete answer to the above question for @xmath0-bridge links with applications to the study of character varieties , mcshane s identity and epimorphisms between @xmath0-bridge link groups .    in the new series of papers , we study the following variation of question  [ question0 ] for @xmath0-bridge spheres of @xmath0-bridge links .    [ question1 ]",
    "consider the even heckoid orbifold @xmath5 of index @xmath3 for the @xmath0-bridge link @xmath1 , and let @xmath25 be a @xmath7-holed sphere in the underlying space @xmath27 obtained from a @xmath0-bridge sphere of @xmath1 .    1 .   which essential simple loops on @xmath25 are null - homotopic , peripheral or torsion in @xmath5 ?",
    "2 .   for two distinct essential simple loops on @xmath25 , when are they homotopic in @xmath5 ?    here the _ even heckoid orbifold , @xmath5 , of index @xmath3 for the @xmath0-bridge link @xmath1 _ is the @xmath23-orbifold as illustrated in figure  [ fig.hekoid-orbifold ] .",
    "the underlying space @xmath27 is the exterior , @xmath28 , of @xmath1 , and the singular set is the lower tunnel of @xmath1 , where the index of the singularity is @xmath3 .     the heckoid orbifold @xmath5 . the labels @xmath29 indicate the parabolic loci . here",
    "@xmath30 with @xmath31=2/9 $ ] , where @xmath32 and @xmath33 , respectively , are the inside and the outside of the bridge sphere @xmath34 .",
    "the lower tunnel is the core tunnel of @xmath32 . ]    as applications , we give ( i ) a systematic construction of upper - meridian - pair preserving epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto heckoid groups , generalizing riley s construction , and ( ii ) the characterization of those epimorphisms onto even heckoid groups .",
    "we also announce applications to character varieties and mcshane s identity .    as in the preceding series of papers ,",
    "the key tool is small cancellation theory , applied to two - generator and one - relator presentations of even heckoid groups .",
    "this note is organized as follows . in section",
    "[ sec : heckoid ] , we explain combinatorial definitions of heckoid orbifolds and heckoid groups and explain that the heckoid groups are identified with @xmath0-parabolic generator kleinian groups . in section  [ statements ] , we describe the main results . in sections  [ application1 ] and [ application2 ] ,",
    "we announce applications of the main results to epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto heckoid groups and to character varieties and mcshane s identity . in section  [ group_presentation ] ,",
    "we give a brief explanation of the ideas for the proofs of the main results .",
    "for a rational number @xmath36 , let @xmath1 be the @xmath0-bridge link of slope @xmath37 , which is defined as the sum @xmath30 of rational tangles of slope @xmath29 and @xmath37 ( cf .",
    "figure  [ fig.hekoid-orbifold ] ) .",
    "the common boundary @xmath38 of the rational tangles is identified with the _ conway sphere _",
    "@xmath39 , where @xmath40 is the group of isometries of the euclidean plane @xmath41 generated by the @xmath42-rotations around the points in the lattice @xmath43 .",
    "let @xmath8 be the @xmath7-punctured sphere @xmath44 in the link complement @xmath45 .",
    "any essential simple loop in @xmath8 , up to isotopy , is obtained as the image of a line of slope @xmath46 in @xmath47 by the covering projection onto @xmath8 .",
    "the ( unoriented ) essential simple loop in @xmath8 so obtained is denoted by @xmath48 .",
    "we also denote by @xmath48 the conjugacy class of an element of @xmath49 represented by ( a suitably oriented ) @xmath48 . the loops @xmath50 and @xmath51 bound disks in @xmath52 and @xmath53 , respectively . thus the _ link group _",
    "@xmath54 is obtained as follows : @xmath55    for each rational number @xmath37 and an integer @xmath56 , the _ even heckoid orbifold of index @xmath3 for the @xmath0-bridge link @xmath1 _ is the @xmath23-orbifold @xmath5 , such that the underlying space @xmath27 is the exterior , @xmath28 , of @xmath1 , and that the singular set is the lower tunnel of @xmath1 ( i.e. , the core tunnel of @xmath33 in the sense of @xcite ) , where the index of the singularity is @xmath3 ( see figure  [ fig.hekoid-orbifold ] ) .",
    "we call the orbifold fundamental group @xmath57 the _ heckoid group of index @xmath3 for @xmath1 _ , and denote it by @xmath35 . since the loop @xmath58 is isotopic to a meridional loop around the lower tunnel , the even hekoid group @xmath6 ( @xmath56 ) is obtained as follows : @xmath59     the case when @xmath1 is a knot and @xmath60 is an odd integer . here",

    "the odd heckoid orbifold @xmath5 ( middle right ) is a @xmath62-covering of @xmath63 ( lower left ) .",
    "the upper left figure is not an orbifold , but is a hyperbolic cone manifold .",
    "the odd heckoid orbifold @xmath5 is the quotient of the cone manifold by the @xmath42-rotation around the axis containing the singular set . ]",
    "the announcement by agol  @xcite and the announcement made in the second author s joint work with akiyoshi , wada and yamashita in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section  3 of preface ) suggest that the group @xmath35 makes sense even when @xmath3 is a half - integer greater than @xmath4 .",
    "we refer to ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition  3.2 ) for the definition of the group @xmath35 and the corresponding orbifold @xmath5 when @xmath3 is a non - integral half - integer greater than @xmath4 .",
    "roughly speaking , @xmath5 is defined to be a @xmath62-covering of a certain orbifold @xmath63 , with @xmath64 , which is obtained from the quotient of @xmath1 by the natural @xmath65-symmetry ( see figure  [ odd - heckoid - orbifold1 ] for the case when @xmath1 is a knot ) .",

    "* proposition  5.3 and figures  5 and 6 ) .",
    "we note that similar orbifolds are studied by @xcite .",
    "our terminology is slightly different from that of riley  @xcite , where @xmath35 is called the heckoid group of index `` @xmath66 '' for @xmath1 with @xmath64 .",

    "[ prop - not - one - relator ] any odd heckoid group is not a one - relator group .",
    "let @xmath10 be the _ farey tessellation _",
    ", that is , the tessellation of the upper half space @xmath68 by ideal triangles which are obtained from the ideal triangle with the ideal vertices @xmath69 by repeated reflection in the edges .",
    "then @xmath70 is identified with the set of the ideal vertices of @xmath10 . for each @xmath71 , let @xmath72 be the group of automorphisms of @xmath10 generated by reflections in the edges of @xmath10 with an endpoint @xmath37 .",

    "the following theorem proved in @xcite is the starting point of all the results which we announce in this note .",
    "[ thm : fundametal_domain ] suppose that @xmath37 is a non - integral rational number and that @xmath3 is an integer or a half integer greater than @xmath4 .",
    "then , for any @xmath46 , there is a unique rational number @xmath94 such that @xmath95 is contained in the @xmath74-orbit of @xmath96 .",
    "moreover @xmath48 is homotopic to @xmath97 in @xmath5 .",
    "in particular , if @xmath98 , then @xmath48 is null - homotopic in @xmath5 .",
    "the following theorem proved in @xcite gives an answer to the first question in question  [ question1](1 ) .",
    "[ thm : null - homotopy ] suppose that @xmath37 is a non - integral rational number and that @xmath3 is an integer with @xmath99 .",
    "then the loop @xmath48 is null - homotopic in @xmath5 if and only if @xmath95 belongs to the @xmath74-orbit of @xmath29 .",
    "in other words , if @xmath100 , then @xmath48 is not null - homotopic in @xmath5 .",
    "the following theorems , which we prove in @xcite , give answers to the remainder of question  [ question1](1 ) and question  [ question1](2 ) .",
    "[ thm : conjugacy ] suppose that @xmath37 is a non - integral rational number and that @xmath3 is an integer with @xmath99 .",
    "for two rational numbers @xmath95 and @xmath101 , the simple loops @xmath48 and @xmath102 are homotopic in @xmath5 if and only if @xmath95 and @xmath101 belong to the same @xmath74-orbit . in other words , for distinct @xmath103 , the simple loops @xmath48 and @xmath102 are not homotopic in @xmath5 .",
    "[ thm : peripheral ] suppose that @xmath37 is a non - integral rational number and that @xmath3 is an integer with @xmath99 .",
    "then the following hold .    1 .",
    "the loop @xmath48 is peripheral in @xmath5 if and only if @xmath95 belongs to the @xmath74-orbit of @xmath29 .",
    "2 .   the loop @xmath48 is torsion in @xmath5 if and only if @xmath95 belongs to the @xmath74-orbit of @xmath29 or @xmath37 .    in other words",
    ", there is no rational number @xmath104 for which the simple loop @xmath48 is peripheral or torsion in @xmath5 .    in the above theorem",
    ", we say that @xmath48 is _ peripheral _ or _ torsion _ if the conjugacy class @xmath48 is represented by a ( possibly trivial ) parabolic or elliptic transformation , respectively , when we identify @xmath35 with a kleinian group generated by two parabolic transformations .",
    "in @xcite , riley discussed relations of the heckoid polynomials with the polynomials defining the nonabelian @xmath105-representations of @xmath0-bridge link groups introduced in @xcite , and proved that each heckoid polynomial divides the nonabelian representation polynomials of @xmath0-bridge links @xmath106 , where @xmath106 belongs to an infinite collection of @xmath0-bridge links determined by @xmath13 and index @xmath107 .",
    "this suggests that there are epimorphisms from the link group of @xmath106 onto the heckoid group of index @xmath107 for @xmath13 , as observed in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* the paragraph following theorem  b in p.391 ) .",
    "the following theorem proved in @xcite gives a systematic construction of epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto heckoid groups , generalizing riley s construction ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 2 ) for precise meaning ) .",
    "[ thm : epimorophism ] suppose that @xmath37 is a rational number and that @xmath3 is an integer or a half - integer greater than @xmath4 .",

    ", riley s construction corresponds to the case when @xmath95 belongs to the orbit of @xmath29 by the infinite cyclic subgroup @xmath76 of @xmath74 .    for even heckoid groups , the following converse to the above theorem",

    "* section  2 ) for precise meaning ) .",
    "[ thm : epimorophism2 ] suppose that @xmath37 is a non - integral rational number and that @xmath3 is an integer with @xmath99 .",
    "then there is an upper - meridian - pair - preserving epimorphism from @xmath109 onto the even heckoid group @xmath35 if and only if @xmath95 or @xmath108 belongs to the @xmath74-orbit of @xmath29 .",
    "we give a characterization of those rational numbers which belong to the @xmath74-orbit of @xmath29 .",

    "for a rational number @xmath37 and an integer @xmath99 , let @xmath153 be the @xmath154-representation of @xmath49 obtained as the composition @xmath155 where the last homomorphism is the holonomy representation of the pared hyperbolic orbifold @xmath5 .",
    "now , let @xmath156 be the once - punctured torus obtained as the quotient @xmath157 , and let @xmath158 be the orbifold @xmath159 where @xmath160 is the group generated by @xmath42-rotations around the points in @xmath161 .",
    "note that @xmath158 is the orbifold with underlying space a once - punctured sphere and with three cone points of cone angle @xmath42 .",
    "the surfaces @xmath156 and @xmath8 , respectively , are @xmath62-covering and @xmath65-covering of @xmath158 , and hence their fundamental groups are identified with subgroups of the orbifold fundamental group @xmath162 of indices @xmath0 and @xmath7 , respectively .",
    "the @xmath154-representation @xmath153 of @xmath49 extends , in a unique way , to that of @xmath162 ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  2.2 ) ) , and so we obtain , in a unique way , a @xmath154-representation of @xmath163 by restriction .",
    "we continue to denote it by @xmath153 .",
    "note that @xmath164 is _ type - preserving _",
    ", i.e. , it satisfies the following conditions .    1",
    ".   @xmath153 is irreducible , i.e. , its image does not have a common fixed point on @xmath165 .",
    "2 .   @xmath153 maps a peripheral element of @xmath163 to a parabolic transformation .    by extending the concept of a geometrically infinite end of a kleinian group ,",
    "bowditch  @xcite introduced the notion of end invariants of a type - preserving @xmath154-representation of @xmath163 .",
    "tan , wong and zhang  @xcite ( cf .",
    "@xcite ) extended this notion ( with slight modification ) to an arbitrary @xmath154-representation of @xmath163 .",
    "( to be precise ,  @xcite and @xcite treat @xmath105-representations .",
    "however , the arguments work for @xmath154-representations . ) to recall the definition of end invariants , let @xmath166 be the set of free homotopy classes of essential simple loops on @xmath156 .",
    "then @xmath166 is identified with @xmath70 , the vertex set of the farey tessellation @xmath10 by the rule @xmath167 .",
    "the projective lamination space @xmath168 of @xmath156 is then identified with @xmath169 and contains @xmath166 as the dense subset of rational points .",
    "[ def_end_invariant ]    let @xmath170 be an @xmath154-representation of @xmath163 .",
    "\\(1 ) an element @xmath171 is an _ end invariant _ of @xmath170 if there exists a sequence of distinct elements @xmath172 such that    1 .",
    "@xmath173 , and 2 .",
    "@xmath174 is bounded from above .",
    "\\(2 ) @xmath175 denotes the set of end invariants of @xmath170 .    in the above definition",
    ", it should be noted that @xmath176 is well - defined though @xmath177 is defined only up to sign .",
    "tan , wong and zhang  @xcite showed that @xmath175 is a closed subset of @xmath168 and proved various interesting properties of @xmath175 , including a characterization of those representations @xmath170 with @xmath178 or @xmath168 , generalizing a result of bowditch  @xcite .",
    "they also proved that @xmath175 is a cantor set in various cases and proposed interesting conjectures . in @xcite",
    ", the authors proved that if @xmath179 corresponds to the faithful discrete representation of a hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge link group @xmath180 , then @xmath181 is equal to the limit set of a certain discrete subgroup of @xmath182 and hence is a cantor set . by using theorems  [ thm : conjugacy ] and [ thm : peripheral ]",
    ", we obtain the following theorem which determines the set @xmath183 .    for a non - integral rational number @xmath37 and an integer @xmath99 ,",
    "the set @xmath183 of end invariants of @xmath153 is equal to the limit set @xmath184 of the group @xmath74 .    in @xcite ,",
    "the authors used the results obtained by the series of papers @xcite to give a variation of mcshane s identity , which expresses the cusp shape of a hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge link in terms of the complex translation lengths of simple loops on the bridge sphere .",
    "( the original mcshane s identity was given by @xcite and variations and applications were given by @xcite . )",
    "theorems  [ thm : null - homotopy ] , [ thm : conjugacy ] and [ thm : peripheral ] , together with a result of bowditch  @xcite , enable us to give a variation of mcshane s identity for heckoid orbifolds for @xmath0-bridge links .",
    "[ thm : mcshane ] for a non - integral rational number @xmath37 and an integer @xmath56 , the following hold : @xmath185    in the above theorem , @xmath186 denotes the simple loop on @xmath156 of slope @xmath95 .",
    "we can refine the above theorem to show that certain partial sums in the above series have geometric meanings . for details",
    ", please see @xcite .",

    "then @xmath200 is represented by the simple loop @xmath51 , and we obtain the following two - generator one - relator presentation of the heckoid group : @xmath201 theorems  [ thm : null - homotopy ] , [ thm : conjugacy ] and [ thm : peripheral ] are proved by applying small cancellation theory to the above presentation . in the remainder of this section , we present key ideas in the proofs of these theorems , by assuming notation in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* sections  58 ) .",
    "suppose that @xmath37 is a rational number with @xmath202 and that @xmath3 is an integer with @xmath99 .",
    "let @xmath78 be the symmetrized subset of @xmath203 generated by the single relator @xmath204 of the presentation @xmath205 .",
    "then we have the following proposition , which enables us to apply small cancellation theory to our problem .",
    "[ prop : small_cancellation_condition_heckoid ] the symmetrized set @xmath78 satisfies @xmath206 and @xmath207 .",
    "thus every reduced @xmath78-diagram is a @xmath208$]-map .    by using basic formulas in small cancellation theory ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  v.3.1 ) ) , we obtain the following proposition .    [",
    "* proposition  4.11 ) ] [ prop : key ] let @xmath209 be an arbitrary connected and simply - connected @xmath210$]-map such that there is no vertex of degree @xmath23 in @xmath211 . put @xmath212 then @xmath213 . in particular , there are at least @xmath214 consecutive vertices of degree @xmath0 on @xmath211 .",
    "this proposition implies that if @xmath48 represents the trivial element of @xmath35 , then the cyclic word @xmath215 contains a subword of the cyclic word @xmath216 which is a product of @xmath217 pieces and is not a product of @xmath214 pieces .",
    "theorem  [ thm : null - homotopy ] is proved by an inductive argument , based on this fact , on the length of the ( positive ) continued fraction expansion of @xmath37 .    in (",
    "* theorem  3 ) ( cf .",
    "* theorem  iv.5.5 ) ) , newman gives a powerful theorem for the word problem for one relator groups with torsion , which implies that if a cyclically reduced word @xmath218 represents the trivial element in @xmath219 , then the cyclic word @xmath220 contains a subword of the cyclic word @xmath216 of length greater than @xmath221 times the length of @xmath222 . on the other hand ,",
    "the above proof of theorem  [ thm : null - homotopy ] is based on the fact that if @xmath223 represents the trivial element in @xmath35 , then the cyclic word @xmath215 contains a subword of the cyclic word @xmath216 which is a product of @xmath217 pieces but is not a product of less than @xmath217 pieces . since @xmath224 is a product of @xmath225-pieces , and since every piece has length less than a half of the length of @xmath192 ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma  4.2 ) ) , this implies that the cyclic word @xmath215 contains a subword of the cyclic word @xmath216 of length greater than @xmath226 times the length of @xmath222 .",
    "this suggests that the above result of newman would not be strong enough to establish theorem  [ thm : null - homotopy ] .    in order to prove theorems  [ thm : conjugacy ] and [ thm : peripheral ] , we establish a structure theorem which describes the possible shapes of annular diagrams over the presentation @xmath227 , as in the structure theorem established in ( * ? ? ? * theorem  4.9 and corollary  4.11 ) ( cf .",
    "* theorem  9.1 ) ) for annular diagrams over the presentation @xmath228 .",
    "[ thm : annular_structure ] let @xmath209 be an arbitrary nontrivial connected annular @xmath210$]-map .",
    "suppose that there is no vertex of degree @xmath4 nor @xmath23 in @xmath211 and that there are no @xmath214 consecutive degree @xmath0 vertices in @xmath211 .",
    "let the outer and inner boundaries of @xmath209 be denoted by @xmath229 and @xmath230 , respectively . then the following hold .    1 .   the outer and inner boundaries @xmath229 and @xmath230 are simple , i.e. , they are homeomorphic to the circle .",
    "2 .   there is no edge contained in @xmath231 .",
    "every vertex of @xmath209 lies in @xmath211 .",
    "4 .   @xmath232 or @xmath7 for every vertex @xmath233 . moreover , if @xmath234 , then between any two vertices of degree @xmath7 there should occur exactly @xmath235 vertices of degree @xmath0 on both @xmath229 and @xmath230 .",
    "@xmath236 for every face @xmath237 .",
    "in particular , figure  [ fig.layer ] illustrates the only two possible shapes of @xmath209 , where the number of faces per layer is variable .",
    "@xmath93 ]    theorems  [ thm : conjugacy ] and [ thm : peripheral ] are proved by an inductive argument , using this structure theorem , on the length of the ( positive ) continued fraction expansion of @xmath37 . for details , please see @xcite .",
    "the second author would like to thank ( i ) gerhard burde for drawing his attention to the work of riley  @xcite when he was staying in frankfurt in @xmath239 , ( ii ) ian agol for sending him a copy of the slides  @xcite in @xmath240 , and ( iii ) gareth jones for sending him riley s personal account @xcite with a postscript by brin , jones and singerman .",
    "both authors would like to thank yeonhee jang , makoto ozawa and toshio saito for helpful discussions and information concerning the proof of theorem  [ thm.kleinian_heckoid ] .",
    "i.  agol , _ the classification of non - free @xmath0-parabolic generator kleinian groups _ , slides of talks given at austin ams meeting and budapest bolyai conference , july 2002 , budapest , hungary , available at http://homepages.math.uic.edu/  agol / parabolic / parabolic01.html      h.  akiyoshi , h.  miyachi and m.  sakuma , _ variations of mcshane s identity for punctured surface groups _ , proceedings of the workshop `` spaces of kleinian groups and hyperbolic 3-manifolds '' , london math .",
    "soc . , lecture note series * 329 * ( 2006 ) , 151185 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> following riley s work , for each @xmath0-bridge link @xmath1 of slope @xmath2 and an integer or a half - integer @xmath3 greater than @xmath4 , we introduce the _ heckoid orbifold @xmath5 _ and the _ heckoid group @xmath6 of index @xmath3 for @xmath1_. when @xmath3 is an integer , @xmath5 is called an _ even _ heckoid orbifold ; in this case , the underlying space is the exterior of @xmath1 , and the singular set is the lower tunnel of @xmath1 with index @xmath3 . </S>",
    "<S> the main purpose of this note is to announce answers to the following questions for even heckoid orbifolds . </S>",
    "<S> ( 1 ) for an essential simple loop on a @xmath7-punctured sphere @xmath8 in @xmath5 determined by the @xmath0-bridge sphere of @xmath1 , when is it null - homotopic in @xmath5 ? ( 2 ) for two distinct essential simple loops on @xmath8 , when are they homotopic in @xmath5 ? </S>",
    "<S> we also announce applications of these results to character varieties , mcshane s identity , and epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto heckoid groups . </S>"
  ]
}
